title: The rise and fall of the medieval Islamic Empire - Petra Sijpesteijn & Birte Kristiansen

multiple-choice.question: In which century did the prophet Muhammad unite the people of the Arabian Peninsula through the formation of Islam?
What was the name of the tribe that controlled Mecca and was also the tribe to which Muhammad belonged?
Who became the new caliph after Muhammad's death, emerging victorious from a contentious question among those close to him?
Which dynasty came to power after the fourth caliph, Ali, was assassinated?
What was the name of the city built by the Abbasid family as their new capital after they overthrew the Umayyad caliphate?
Under Abbasid rule, what was the lifestyle of the elite like, thanks to extensive trade networks that brought products and people from all over the known world to Baghdad?
Who were the Mongols, and what was their impact on the city of Baghdad in 1258 CE?

options.label: A
options.text: They were a powerful empire that approached Baghdad, thoroughly destroyed the city, and rolled the caliph in a rug to be trampled to death.

options.label: B
options.text: They were local leaders who overthrew the caliph, and the city was destroyed.

options.label: C
options.text: They were a rival dynasty that conquered the city and made it their capital.

options.label: D
options.text: They were a nomadic tribe that pillaged the city and killed the caliph.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Mongols' destruction of Baghdad in 1258 CE?

options.label: A
options.text: The caliph was able to maintain his power and the city was rebuilt.

options.label: B
options.text: The city was rebuilt, and the caliph was restored to power.

options.label: C
options.text: The city was laid bare, and a longstanding reality was revealed: the caliphs had ruled mostly symbolically.

options.label: D
options.text: The city was destroyed, and the caliph was rolled in a rug and trampled to death.

multiple-choice.question: Who benefited from the extensive trade networks that brought products and people from all over the known world to Baghdad under Abbasid rule?

options.label: D
options.text: The Abbasid family and the elite

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the ideas of the greatest intellectuals of the Islamic Empire on the world?

options.label: A
options.text: They had no impact and were forgotten.

options.label: B
options.text: They had a limited impact and were only known in the Middle East.

options.label: C
options.text: They left a lasting mark on the world through written and spoken Arabic, Islam, and their ideas.

options.label: D
options.text: They were only known in Europe and had no impact on the Middle East.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the tribe that was in power when Muhammad was born?
Who was the first caliph after Muhammad's death?
Which dynasty came to power after the Umayyad caliphate was overthrown?
What was the name of the city that was built by the Abbasid family as their new capital?

options.label: A
options.text: The caliph was able to maintain his power and the city was rebuilt.

options.label: B
options.text: The city was rebuilt, and the caliph was restored to power.

options.label: C
options.text: The city was laid bare, and a longstanding reality was revealed: the caliphs had ruled mostly symbolically.

options.label: D
options.text: The city was destroyed, and the caliph was rolled in a rug and trampled to death.

title: Can you guess what's wrong with these paintings? - Noah Charney

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason why art restorers from the past often modified paintings?

options.label: D
options.text: They were commissioned to alter the paintings

options.text: Today, they use more heavily intervene in the original work

options.label: B
options.text: Today, they focus on keeping the original work intact with minimal intervention

options.label: C

options.text: Today, they only work on paintings from the 16th century

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.text: He thought it was too expensive

options.label: B
options.text: Repairing the slashes in the painting

options.label: C
options.text: Replacing the missing pieces of the painting

options.label: D
options.text: Restoring the colors of the painting

What is the primary goal of art conservators?

options.label: C

title: Why a sausage can do what your gloves cannot - Charles Wallace and Sajan Saini

multiple-choice.question: How do touchscreens work?

options.label: B
options.text: By using a combination of capacitance and electric fields

options.label: C
options.text: By using a combination of optical sensors and cameras

options.label: D
options.text: By using a combination of mechanical switches and levers

options.text: Conductors have a higher density than insulators

options.label: B
options.text: Conductors have a lower density than insulators

options.label: C
options.text: Conductors have weakly bound electrons, while insulators have tightly bound electrons

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B, as well as objects that conduct electricity about as well as a user's finger

multiple-choice.question: What type of objects can activate a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: C
options.text: Objects that conduct electricity about as well as a user's finger

options.label: C

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why multinational corporations are able to exploit Mali's need for tax revenue?

options.text: They filter their profits through a labyrinth of tax havens

options.label: C
options.text: The citizens of gold-rich countries benefit from the increased revenue

options.label: D

options.text: They are able to access public goods such as healthcare and education

title: What causes yeast infections, and how do you get rid of them? - Liesbeth Demuyser

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main functions of Lactobacilli bacteria in the vagina?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce an acid that lowers the vagina's pH, limiting what can survive there and preventing certain infections

options.label: B
options.text: To combat and outcompete Candida yeasts for nutrients and territory

options.label: C
options.text: To secrete enzymes that degrade epithelial cells

options.label: D
options.text: To permeate the tissue of the vagina

options.label: A
options.text: They multiply and assume their disease-causing forms, such as elongated thread-like forms called hyphae

options.label: B
options.text: They decrease in number and become harmless

options.label: C
options.text: They secrete enzymes that degrade epithelial cells

options.label: D
options.text: They permeate the tissue of the vagina

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the symptoms of a yeast infection?

options.label: B
options.text: A change in vaginal discharge, making it thicker and whiter

options.label: C
options.text: An increase in the number of Lactobacilli bacteria

options.label: D
options.text: A decrease in the number of Candida yeasts

multiple-choice.question: What can make people more susceptible to vaginal yeast infections?

What is one of the causes of recurrent yeast infections in some people?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetic factors, such as gene variants that make it harder for their immune systems to recognize and regulate Candida cells

options.label: D
options.text: It is not relevant to human health

title: The world’s slimiest animal - Noah R. Bressman and Douglas Fudge

multiple-choice.question: What incident in 2017 resulted in the United States resulted in a massive amount of hagfish slime being spilled on a highway?

options.label: A
options.text: A group of hagfish escaped from a lab.

options.label: B
options.text: A storm caused a hagfish farm to flood.

options.label: C
options.text: A truck carrying hagfish slid off the road and spilled its contents.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people intentionally released hagfish into the wild.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main strength of hagfish?

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to eat a lot of food.

multiple-choice.question: Why is hagfish slime effective at defending against predators?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is very hard and can crush predators' teeth.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is very soft and can't harm predators.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can lodge in predators' gills and cause them to suffocate.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it can blind predators with its bright color.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the structure of hagfish slime?

options.label: A
options.text: It is made up of a single type of protein fiber.

options.label: B
options.text: It is made up of a single type of mucus cell.

options.label: C
options.text: It is made up of both mucus and protein fibers that can expand to 10,000 times their original volume.

options.label: D
options.text: It is made up of a mixture of different types of cells.

multiple-choice.question: How do hagfish get rid of their own slime after using it to defend themselves?

options.label: B
options.text: They use a special tool to wipe it away.

options.label: C
options.text: They tie themselves in a knot to wipe away the slime.

options.label: D
options.text: They use their slime to trap their predators.

multiple-choice.question: What are some potential applications of hagfish slime?

options.label: A
options.text: Making athletic gear that is more comfortable.

options.label: B
options.text: Making safety gear that is more durable.

options.label: C
options.text: Making non-lethal weapons that can be used to stop boats.

multiple-choice.question: How many hearts do hagfish have?
How long can hagfish survive without oxygen?
What role do hagfish play in the ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They are predators that hunt other fish.

options.label: B
options.text: They are prey that are hunted by other fish.

options.label: C
options.text: They help to clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients.

options.label: D
options.text: They do all of the above.

multiple-choice.question: How long have hagfish been on Earth?
What is unique about the way hagfish use their slime to defend themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: They use it to blind their predators.

options.label: B
options.text: They use it to trap their predators.

options.label: C
options.text: They use it to suffocate their predators by lodging it in their gills.

options.label: D
options.text: They use it to distract their predators.

multiple-choice.question: How do hagfish use their slime to clean the seafloor?

options.label: A
options.text: By eating the slime-covered food particles.

options.label: B
options.text: By using the slime to trap and remove debris.

options.label: C
options.text: By secreting the slime to cover and conceal their food particles.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the barometric pressure at an altitude of 8,848 meters compared to sea level?

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of altitude sickness (AMS) at high altitudes?
What triggers a response to increase the rate and depth of breathing at high altitudes?

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the volume of plasma in the blood within the first few days above 1,500 meters?

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases, increasing the concentration of hemoglobin

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the increased concentration of hemoglobin in the blood after several weeks at high altitude?

options.label: D
options.text: The blood can carry even more oxygen per milliliter

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when breathing increases even further after several weeks at high altitude?

options.label: B
options.text: Oxygen deprivation and carbon dioxide buildup

multiple-choice.question: What genetic advantages do some Tibetans and South Americans have that can prevent minor altitude sickness?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That humans can live at high altitudes without acclimatization

options.label: C
options.text: That humans can push past their body's limitations

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It is the world's largest world history museum, drawing millions of visitors every year.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a museum specializing in ancient Egyptian artifacts.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The museum has too many artifacts and needs to downsize.

options.text: The museum's collection is too focused on Western art.

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: It was a mission to retrieve the Benin bronzes from the British Museum.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a mission to conquer the city of Benin and burn it to the ground.

options.label: C
